&bibliography; Network Motifs
Large networks can be decomposed into smaller building blocks or networks-within-networks, commonly referred to as motifs.
Every network can be uniquely decomposed into a set of motifs, and the number and distribution of individual motifs can reflect some functional characteristics of the network Sporns 2011.
motifs-dyads Dyads
= Two actors and their ties
At the most basic level, a link establishes a relationship between two nodes. The link is a property of the pair, not of any single node...
Dyadic analysis focuses on the properties of pairwise relationships, e.g. reciprocity.
Wasserman and Faust 1994: chapters 13, 15 & 16...
motifs-triads Triads
= Three actors and their ties
++ Transitivity (if A likes B and B likes C, then A will like C)
++ Balance (if A and B like each other, they will have a similar opinion of C; if they dislike each other, they will not agree on C)
Wasserman and Faust 1994: chapters 6 and 14...
motifs-cliques Cliques, plexes & cores
motifs-components Components & k-components
motifs-structural-balance Appendix: Structural balance
Stuctural balance, postulated by Fritz Heider in the 1940's Heider 1946 and Theodore M. Newcomb in the 1950's Newcomb 1953, led to research on triples of individuals, since balanced relations are common in empirical work...
Cartwright and Harary 1956 were among the first to quantify structural balance...
Balance theory influenced the development of other structural theories, such as transitivity...
